title: Breached Password Detection - Leaked credentials are blocked
public-title: Breached Password Detection - Leaked credentials are blocked
description:
Enable Breach Password Detection and Create a user with the previously created breached email/password combo

### Requirements


### Steps



1. Enable Breach Password Detection in the Security > Attack Protection section of the dashboard. Also configure this feature to: Notify user, Block compromised user accounts, and Notify administrators IMMEDIATELY

2. Create a user from the management console with the email set to "leak-functional-test@example.com" and the password set to "E2EPaaf213XXYYZZ".

3. Log in with that user and verify the blocked message: WE HAVE DETECTED A POTENTIAL SECURITY ISSUE WITH THIS ACCOUNT. TO PROTECT YOUR ACCOUNT, WE HAVE BLOCKED THIS LOGIN. AN EMAIL WAS SENT WITH INSTRUCTION ON HOW TO UNBLOCK YOUR ACCOUNT.

4. In the management console go to Logs > Search and a Breach Password event (pwd_leak) should report of the breached password detection. 

5. The email Inbox of the user should have an email with the subject: Please change your password immediately. The Change Password in the body of the message should open the Change Password page.

6. The email inbox of the administrator should have an email with the subject: Use of breached password detected. The body of the message should display the leaked email.

title: Login as Delegated Admin - User and Validate Permissions are accurately reflected in the dashboard
public-title: Login as Delegated Admin - User and Validate Permissions are accurately reflected in the dashboard
description:
### Requirements
In this scenario we are checking that Delegated Admin - User can login on the dashbaord
Checking if Permissions are accurately reflected in the dashboard
Validate that Admin User can Search for users create users, open users, delete or block user.
### Steps
1.Register/Create a new application with Auth0. client type is SPA with those details:
allowed_logout_urls: `https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin`,
      app_type: "spa",
      callbacks: [
        `https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin/login`,
        `https://auth0-stage2-${tenantInfo.tenant}.stage12.webtask.io/auth0-delegated-admin/login`,
      ],
2.Create a new db connection.
3.Disable all other connections for the Auth0 Application
4.Enabled this connection to the new SPA client created
5.Create a new Delegate Admin Extension.
6.Create a role for user with those details:  Role:"Delegated Admin - Administrator", Description:"Search for users, create users, open users, and execute actions on users (such as delete or block)."
7.Assigne Role to User
8.Login with the new user created.
9.Go to extension tab
10.Install and configure the extension
11.Click the Extension Button
12.Wait and go to DAE dashboard
13.Login with the new user that is created
14.Go to Actions Drop Down
15.Validate that can see:
    Block User
    Reset Password
    Resend Verification Email
    Change Email
    Change Password
    Delete User
16.Validate that admin user can block user
17.Validate that admin user can delete user
18.Clear the user searched and validate that user is deleted
19.Validate that admin user can create a new user

### Result
DAE Admin User can Search for users create users, open users, delete or block user.

title: Enforce MFA DUO @auth @mfa
public-title: Enforce MFA DUO
description:
### Requirements
Cisco Duo account.
Auth0 Enterprise account.

### Steps
Follow https://auth0.com/docs/secure/multi-factor-authentication/configure-cisco-duo-for-mfa
Create a Duo Security Web SDK integration and capture the Integration Key, Secret Key, and API hostname credentials.
Enable Duo Security as a multi factor authenticator (only Duo needs to be enabled).
Link your Duo account by providing the details obtained before.
Set Require Multi-factor Auth to always.
Pickup and arbitrary user and try logging in.
Enter email and password.

### Expected result
It should prompt the user to enroll with Duo (if the password is correct).
It should succesfully finish the enrolment.
It should challenge Duo during subsequent logins.
It should succesfully verify Duo during subsequent logins (if the user approves it).

title: Adaptive MFA - Email OTP flow
public-title: Adaptive MFA - Email OTP flow
description:
### Requirements

### Steps

1. Use the [ModHeader extension](https://bewisse.com/modheader/) for Chrome to add a custom header that will trigger the aMFA:

```
    Key: x-auth0-trust-reducer

    Value: 100
```

1. Go to Security > Multi-factor Auth, enable the One-time Password factor and select the Adaptive MFA policy at the bottom of the page.

1. Go to Connections > Database >  Username-Password-Authentication > Try Connection. A new page should pop up with the Login page. It should display the username/password fields combo.

1. With a valid user account that uses an email address for which you have access to the inbox, try to login with a valid password. 

1. The server should display a page asking the user to enter a One Time Password.

1. Open the E-mail inbox of the email used in the login. Copy the One Time Password found in the email sent and paste it into the One Time Password page.  

1. The server should return the It Works! page.

1. In the management console go to Monitoring > Logs and search for ALL the following events. The order can vary, but :

```
Guardian - Email verification sent

Guardian - Email verification confirmed

Success Login

Success Exchange
```

1. Open the "Success Login" event and find in the JSON object with the data the `context.riskAssessment` object:
```
"riskAssessment": {
  "confidence": "low",
  "version": "1",
  "assessments": {
    "UntrustedIP": {
      "confidence": "high",
      "code": "not_found_on_deny_list"
    },
    "NewDevice": {
      "confidence": "high",
      "code": "match",
      "details": {
        "device": "known",
        "useragent": "known"
      }
    },
    "ImpossibleTravel": {
      "confidence": "high",
      "code": "minimal_travel_from_last_login"
    }
  },
  "effects": [
    {
      "name": "TrustReducerHeader",
      "preEffectScore": 1,
      "postEffectScore": 0
    }
  ]
}
```

title: Long Lived Sessions (long_lived_refresh_token_lifetime flag)
public-title: Long Lived Sessions (long_lived_refresh_token_lifetime flag)
description:
### Requirements

Set `long_lived_refresh_token_lifetime` flag to true for a tenant in belgrano.

### Steps

Log into manage dashboard for the tenant with the flag DISABLED.
Go to an application and scroll to the Refresh Token Expiration section.
Enable Absolute Expiration.
Attempt to change the Absolute Expiration to more than 31557600; this should fail (this is 365.25 days in seconds)

Change the flag to true.
Allow enough time for belgrano caching to expire and reload the page.
You should be able to change the Absolute Expiration higher than 31557600 but less than 157680000 (5 years)

description:

https://YOUR_DOMAIN/v2/logout?
  client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&
  returnTo=LOGOUT_URL

- To verify that the user is logged out, call the same URL as the Try button of the basic Database connection,

title: Write a filter hook that will exclude the Delegated Admin - Administrator from showing up in the list for other non-admin users
public-title: Write a filter hook that will exclude the Delegated Admin - Administrator from showing up in the list for other non-admin users
description:
### Requirements
Write a filter hook scenario that will exclude the "Delegated Admin - Administrator" from showing up in the list of users for all the "non-admin" users
Login as delegated Admin - Administrator
Go to configration create hook filter hook
Validate that everybody else(anyother user) should see only 3 other users including admin but not admin user
Test filter hook is working
### Steps
1.Register/Create a new application with Auth0. client type is SPA with those details:
allowedlogouturls: https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin,
app_type: "spa",
callbacks: [
https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin/login,
https://auth0-stage2-${tenantInfo.tenant}.stage12.webtask.io/auth0-delegated-admin/login,
],
2.Create a new db connection.
3.Disable all other connections for the Auth0 Application
4.Enabled this connection to the new SPA client created
5.Create a new Delegate Admin Extension.
6.Create a role for user with those details:
Role:"Delegated Admin - Auditor",
Description:"Search for users and view user information, but not make changes. Action-based buttons are not visible to this role."
7.Assigne Role to User
8.Login with the new user created.
9.Go to extension tab
10.Install and configure the extension
11.Click the Extension Button
12.Wait and go to DAE dashboard
13.Login with delegate admin administration user details
14.Open user details Drop Down
15.Go to Configuration Drop Down Option and select Configuration
16.Go to filter hook text area under configuration page and create a new filter hook
17.Add this filter hook 
`function(ctx, callback) { ctx.log(ctx); 
  return callback(null, '-app_metadata.roles:"Delegated Admin - Administrator"');
}`
18.Save filter
19.Logout 
20.Login as a Delegated Admin User
21.Search for the admin user 
22.Validate that this admin user in not present.There are only 3 users present

description:
### Requirements

- Automated tests are passing
- Env is public-cloud and not layer0.

### Steps

- Log into the AWS console for the env.
- Find the S3 bucket for the tenant logs backups.
    - Should be named like `{env}-tlog-backup-s3-{region}`
- Make sure the bucket contains recent logs (up to the last 5 minutes)
    - Generate some logs if env is really quiet
- Validate that the content is not corrupted:
    - Download a recent file. It should be a `journal-{datetime}-{datetime}-{uuid}.jl.gzip` file.
    - Unzip it (`gunzip {file}`)
    - Check that it contains valid JSON lines. For example `cat {file} | head | jq`

title: Generate reusable refresh token and exchange it @automatable
public-title: Generate reusable refresh token and exchange it
description:
### Requirements

Existing tenant
Create at least one user with a password for the tenant

### Steps

Create a new API.  Make sure to enable "Allow Offline Access" for the API.

Go to Applications, there should be a test application for the API.  Scroll to advanced settings/Grant Types and check all boxes (Refresh Token, Password, client Credentials, implicit, etc.)

For now leave Refresh Token Rotation and Refresh Token Expiration disabled.

Submit a POST request to https://domain/oauth/token: with www-form-urlencoded payload
- grant_type: "password"
- client_id, client_secret from application
- audience from API
- username, password: for existing user
- scope: "openid profile offline_access"

Expected response: 200 code
JSON body containing: 
{
    "access_token": ...,
    "refresh_token": ...,
    "id_token": ...,
    "scope": "openid profile offline_access",
    "expires_in": 86400,
    "token_type": "Bearer"
}

Copy the refresh_token value.

Submit a POST request to https://domain/oauth/token:
- grant_type: "refresh_token"
- client_id, client_secret from application
- refresh_token: from above

Expected response: 200 code
JSON body containing:
{
    "access_token": ...,
    "id_token": ...,
    "scope": "openid profile offline_access",
    "expires_in": 86400,
    "token_type": "Bearer"
}

You should be able to exchange the same refresh token multiple times successfully.

public-title: Write an access hook scenario that makes sure that the non-Delegated Admin - Admin users cannot access the Delegated Admin - Admin user account
description:
### Requirements
Write an access hook scenario that makes sure that the non-"Delegated Admin - Admin" 
users cannot access the "Delegated Admin - Admin" user account.
Validate that non-admin user can not see details for Admin admin user

### Steps

1.Register/Create a new application with Auth0. client type is SPA with those details:
allowedlogouturls: https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin,
app_type: "spa",
callbacks: [
https://${tenantInfo.tenant}.sus.webtask.run/auth0-delegated-admin/login,
https://auth0-stage2-${tenantInfo.tenant}.stage12.webtask.io/auth0-delegated-admin/login,
],
2.Create a new db connection.
3.Disable all other connections for the Auth0 Application
4.Enabled this connection to the new SPA client created
5.Create a new Delegate Admin Extension.
6.Create a role for user with those details:
Role:"Delegated Admin - Auditor",
Description:"Search for users and view user information, but not make changes. Action-based buttons are not visible to this role."
7.Assigne Role to User
8.Login with the new user created.
9.Go to extension tab
10.Install and configure the extension
11.Click the Extension Button
12.Wait and go to DAE dashboard
13.Login with delegate admin administration user details
14.Open user details Drop Down
15.Go to Configuration Drop Down Option and select Configuration
16.Go to Access hook text area under configuration page and create a new acccess hook that prevent non-admin user to see admin user.
17.Add this access hook
  `function(ctx, callback) {
        ctx.log(ctx);
     if (ctx.payload.action === 'read:user') {
      return callback(new Error('You are not allowed to read users.'));
    }
       return callback();
      } `

18.Save access hook
19.Logout
20.Login as a Delegated Admin - Auditor
21.Search for the admin user
22.Validate that this admin user in not present.No users found by given parameters.

title: Applogs verification
public-title: Applogs verification
description:
We want to make sure that some important applog entries are captured and queryable in Kibana/OpenSearch. We also want to ensure that no error logs are emitted, that could be symptomatic of mis-configuration.

### Requirements

### Steps

1. Open the Kibana or OpenSearch Dashboard for your environment/space
  a. Public Cloud: See [Instructions](https://auth0team.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DPLATF/pages/695338283/AppLogs+Kibana)
  b. Layer0: See [Instructions](https://auth0team.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DPLATF/pages/2408644714/How+to+Access+Converged+Platform+Observability+Tools+i.e.+Datadog+Kibana+and+Lightstep#OpenSearch-Dashboards)
1. For each service below, check that the relevant logs are present and that no unexpected errors are logged.

#### Service: guemes-data-expiry

- The job runs once per hour and we should a couple log entries every hour, with no errors.

Public Cloud:
_This lambda does not export logs to Kibana. Open an AWS Console, navigate to the `guemes-data-expiry` lambda for the specified AWS region and look at Cloudwatch logs._

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND kubernetes.container_name:"guemes-data-expiry"
```

#### Service: tlog-anomaly-detection-lambda

- This service emits a limited nb of logs to have a low level of noise, but it still emits some error logs if there are any, and in layer0, we are logging some initialization logs.

Public Cloud:
_This lambda does not export logs to Kibana. Open an AWS Console, navigate to the `tlog-anomaly-detection-lambda` lambda for the specified AWS region and look at Cloudwatch logs._

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND process.app:"tlog-anomaly-detection-lambda"
```

#### Service: credstuff

- Initialization and request logs should be visible whenever we assess the score for a given login request.

Public Cloud:
1. Open index `logs_credstuff-*`
1. Check that we have various `log_type` values (ex. `response` and `credstuff_score_result`)

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND kubernetes.container_name:"credstuff"
```

#### Service: breach-importer


- The job runs once per hour and we should see a couple log entries every hour, with no errors. Also, every few days, there should be new data to import, which will show larger volumes and more varied log entries.

Public Cloud:
1. Open index `logs_breach-importer-*`
1. Check that we have various `log_type` values and no errors.

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND kubernetes.container_name:"breach-importer"
```

#### Service: guemes-untrusted-importer

- The job runs once per hour and we should see a couple log entries every hour, with no errors.

Public Cloud:
_This lambda does not export logs to Kibana. Open an AWS Console, navigate to the `guemes-untrusted-importer` lambda for the specified AWS region and look at Cloudwatch logs. Note that this service is only deployed in prod-us, where it inserts records in a central PG database, which is then replicated to all public cloud envs._

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND kubernetes.labels.app:"untrusted-ip-importer"
```

#### Service: server

There is a variety of useful log entries directly logged by `server`. Here are a few `log_type` values that are relevant to check:

Public Cloud:
1. Open index `logs_server-*`
1. Query for relevant log types: `log_type:[too_many_signups, account_blocked, many_different_usernames_attempts, pwd_breach_detected, too_many_login_attempts_same_user, anomaly_assess_result]`

Layer0:
```
space.keyword:"my-space-name" AND kubernetes.labels.app:"server" AND log_type:[too_many_signups, account_blocked, many_different_usernames_attempts, pwd_breach_detected, too_many_login_attempts_same_user, anomaly_assess_result]
```

title: Generate rotating token and exchange it @automatable
public-title: Generate rotating token and exchange it
description:
### Requirements

Existing tenant
Create at least one user with a password for the tenant

### Steps

Create a new API.  Make sure to enable "Allow Offline Access" for the API.

Go to Applications, there should be a test application for the API.  Scroll to advanced settings/Grant Types and check all boxes (Refresh Token, Password, client Credentials, implicit, etc.)

Enable "Refresh Token Rotation"; you can leave "Reuse Interval" at 0.  For now leave Refresh Token Expiration disabled.

Submit a POST request to https://domain/oauth/token: with www-form-urlencoded payload
- grant_type: "password"
- client_id, client_secret from application
- audience from API
- username, password: for existing user
- scope: "openid profile offline_access"

Expected response: 200 code
JSON body containing: 
{
    "access_token": ...,
    "refresh_token": ...,
    "id_token": ...,
    "scope": "openid profile offline_access",
    "expires_in": 86400,
    "token_type": "Bearer"
}

Copy the refresh_token value.

Submit a POST request to https://domain/oauth/token:
- grant_type: "refresh_token"
- client_id, client_secret from application
- refresh_token: from above

Expected response: 200 code
JSON body containing:
{
    "access_token": ...,
    "id_token": ...,
    "refresh_token": ...,
    "scope": "openid profile offline_access",
    "expires_in": 86400,
    "token_type": "Bearer"
}

Since this is a rotating token, the response contains a NEW refresh_token.

1. You should be able to exchange the new rotating token for another rotating token.
2. You should NOT be able to exchange a rotating token more than once

description:
### Requirements

### Steps
"For this feature you'll need 2 tenants, one tenant acting as IDP (with a database connection and at least one active user), and another tenant that will consume the IDP tenants with an OIDC enterprise connection.

On the IDP tenant, create an application of tyoe Web Applicaiton and enable the database connection, with at least one active user.
You'll need to come back to this application and configure the callback URL provided on the next step.

On the other tenant setup an OIDC enterprise connection with the following details
Issuer URL: your auth0 domain url
Type: front channel
ClientID: the client id fron the application created on the idp tenant
Scopes: openid profile email

Once you save the connection, go to the connection details and copy the callback url and paste it in the client created in the first step"

title: SSO Dashboard Extension - Create an app and test a login request

description:
### Requirements
- Create a tenant 
- On the dashboard, go to extensions and install the SSO Dashboard.
- Create an application (on Auth0, not on the SSO dashboard, any but m2m), enable the SAML addon on it. Indicate any callback URL you want. 

### Steps
Notes: This test is about surfacing the feature, not a deep test of the app. https://auth0.com/docs/customize/extensions/single-sign-on-dashboard-extension/add-applications-to-the-sso-dashboard

- Open the SSO dashboard
- Go to settings 
- Create an application. Select the Auth0 you created (with the SAML addon) 
- Try the application, you should be logged in. 
- To check this, open the netwprk tool of the browser, and verify the HTTP request made to your callback, there must be an SAML Response. 
- base64 decode the SAMLResponse, there must be ```<status><statuscode value="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:status:Success"></statuscode></status>```

title: Check Rate Limit: POST /dbconnections/change_password @ratelimit
public-title: Check Rate Limit: POST /dbconnections/change_password
description:
### Requirements
Run this script in the command line
```
for i in $(seq 1000)
do
  curl --request POST \
  --url 'https://YOUR_DOMAIN/dbconnections/change_password' \
  --header 'content-type: application/json' \
  --data '{"client_id": "<your_client_id>","email": "<your_email>","connection": "<your_db_connection_name>"}'
  echo $i
done
```

### Steps
1. Update the script with your client id, email and db connection name
2. Run script in command line 
3. Verify that you're seeing the call getting rate limited
</your_db_connection_name></your_email></your_client_id>

title: User Import - Send results email works
public-title: User Import - Send results email works
description:
### Requirements
Import users send results email should work
### Steps
Have a sample import users file, which also has mfa factor specified
https://auth0.com/docs/secure/multi-factor-authentication/authenticate-using-ropg-flow-with-mfa/import-user-mfa-authenticator-enrollments#bulk-user-import
Next import the users using the bulk import endpoints using
curl --request POST --url 'https://XYZ/api/v2/jobs/users-imports' --header
"authorization: Bearer $ACCESSTOKEN" --header 'content-type: multipart/form-data' --form users=@user5.json --form connectionid='conDmV16RTRAxeuAOv0' --form upsert='true' --form sendcompletion_email='true'
Check that the job doesnt have any errors
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer $ACCESS_TOKEN"
https://XYZ/api/v2/jobs/.
Note the jobID comes as a result from the previous step.
This should send emails to the tenant admins.
Note: In case of Layer0 , the tenant admins needs to be part of the Root config users.
